May 1, 195>2
Mr. Seymour Siegel
President, NAEB
New York City, N.Y.
Dear Sis
I was out of the office all last week and this is my first
opportunity this week to bring you up-to-date on the NAEB meeting
in Columbus. Since you met with Jim at the Pennsylvania fiasco,
I assume that he will have filled you in on most of the details.
Little remains for me to say except that I am indeed sorry that
you were not present for all of the meetings and everyone else
was very much of the same opinion. Actually, Columbus represented
the fruition of many of the things you have fought hardest for
and it was unfortunate that you were not there to receive credit
for the good fight that you have fought.
In reviewing, as I have done many times, our meetings with
Fletcher, I am firmly of the opinion that we did the only thing
we could have done in regard to the big project. I am further of
the opinion that we will have very little voice in any project
undertaken in regard to television production or anything else and
our choice is simply, do we get the programs on their terms or do
we not get the programs, and again I came up with only one answer
and that is that we must have the programs. Very frankly, I think
I have reached the point you reached prior to Columbus and my
one feeling at this point is that it is a battle which we have lost
and I, for one, am ready to quit. The whole thing is a little
bit more than a personal sense of failure for I feel that in this
case the democratic process itself has failed in the face of power¬
ful dictatorial forces.
One of the disturbing things to me was the $80,000 grant and
Fletcher's positive statement that it was not a grant to be ad¬
ministered by NAEB at all but strictly through Jim Miles with no
reference to an NAEB comittee or board. I was more disturbed at
the vindictive manner of our friend who had told Jim privately *
and me privately that the grant was not to NAEB but to the Executive
Director, Jim Miles, and then repeated his question to Fletcher
when we were all together. I am still of the opinion that we should
control the fund through the committee we appointed to work with
Jim—-Bunn, Abbot, and Waggner. If this committee cannot continue
to function, then I suggest we write the Foundation and tell them
we don’t want the money. To have our Executive Director endanger
